A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1912, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer diet

- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires so that we may begin to preserve them for future generations.

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ........................................... GEORGE G. CRAIG

2. Your address ............................................. NETHERHILL

3. Date ......................................................... August 17, 1954

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) .................. Beith Ayrshire Scotland

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ................................ John Craig Mason (Stone) Building Contractor

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year) .......... June 1906

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. ........................................ Only in Scotland

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).

9. What were your reasons for coming West? ...................................... As building construction was pretty well all finished in Ayrshire, a move had to be made! The choice was Canada! Some consideration was given to moving to Rosyth (Scotland) where the Government was constructing the large Naval Base, but Canada was the ultimate choice!

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) ........................................ Mainly through the Canadian Govt. Immigration Office at St. Enoch Square in Glasgow, whose head was Mr. Bruce Walker. (Mr. Walker gave the letter of introduction.) When we arrived in Winnipeg, my father had a letter of introduction to Mr. Obie Smith who held some position in Lands Settlement! Who said he had a party surveying land suitable for settlement in the Eagle Lake District 140 miles west of Saskatoon! When this party returned, Mr. Smith gave my father the number of the land lot just up there! This land was piled upon Blinds Hill & turned out to be a parcel of the best land in Saskatchewan!

2. Your address: NETHERHILL
3. Date: August 17, 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Auchterarder, Scotland
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John Craig, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): From 1906
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Only in Scotland
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Mainly through the Canadian Govt. Immigration Office at St. Louis, Missouri. (Mr. Smith gave me the idea of immigrating to Canada.) After the answers in answering my friend had a letter of introduction to Mr. Old Smith who has a farm owning land near Saskatoon. I went there first. Later Mr. Smith gave my family the number of the land we purchased. We bought the land from Mr. Smith.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

In 1906 Canada was thought to be a land of the snow and cowboys! When Indians anyone who went there was considered crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

The family all came together.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

The Allan Line, Saskatchewan, the C.P.R., to Regina, Saskatoon, and back from Saskatoon to the homesteads in Section 32, Township 29, Range 21 W3, a distance then of probably 140 miles.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Nothing much, we got our share of mosquitoes, bad water, lightning storms, found out the best way to get the wagons out when they got mired in the old sloughs. We used the old Bone Trail as far as it went, I made a new one from its end. The wildest beasts we encountered were mosquitoes.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the old Western Hotel, Saskatoon. Jim Flanagan was the owner, he afterwards built the Senator Hotel.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Section 33, Township 29, Range 21 W3.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have spent several winters in BC, mostly at Qualicum Beach, V.I., New Westminster, Port Moody in the Lower Mainland.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I was in the Civil Service; being a telegraph operator in the General Post Office in Glasgow.

horse. Distance 26 & 30 miles!
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

In 1906, Canada was thought to be a land of unlimited opportunity.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

The family was large together.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

The C.P.R. to Regina, Saskatchewan.

Then from Saskatchewan to the homestead in Section 32, Township 28, Range 21, in Athabasca, Alberta, approximately 110 miles.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Many times we got our share of misadventures, hardship, starvation, sickness, and the loss of many lives. The wagons and what they got inside the抵达的骆驼。All used the old Bone Trail as far as it went, and then we turned off from its end at the nearest bench to the homestead, three miles further.

At the old Western Hotel, North Battleford.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Section 32, Township 28, Range 21.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

How, after you came?

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Quite often for the first few years, not so often afterwards.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Mrs. Elsie May Broughton, 28 May 1932, at Kindersley Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Probably, but can't say definitely.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Brother David died in July 1908 (Hearne, Alberta)
Sister Jean died in Dec. 1918 (Saskatoon)
Sister Agnes married in 1912 now living in Cleveland Ohio
Sister Jessie married in 1923 now living in Saskatoon
Sister Janet married in 1924 now living in Victoria BC
Sister Alice married in 1942 now living in Toad B.C.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Yes, but would take too long to recount them. I have been lost in blizzards, almost drowned & death, my life & that of two other chaps depended on one single match in a cellar of a half built house in a cold storm in the winter of 1906-7. I saw a well at least one settler I found the bodies of three men in a tent that was struck by lightning in the old Swift Current & Battleford Trail north of Sask Landing.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Not much except for trips to the Bad Hills, the South River for wood & to Saskatoon at least twice a year for supplies. Oxen for Saskatoon & wood. Saddle Horse for anything up to 50 miles. Not too often, although we did carry the mail from Beraston 6-32-18 across the Bad Hills when the ground was too muddy for a buggy. The mail was carried by saddle horse. Distance 26 to 30 miles.

25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1912.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? None.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Saskatoon for 3 years, a distance of 10 miles, after 1909 Netherhill 8½ miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

I use generally are in Kindersley at least once a week! Sometimes often.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? From 1906 to 1909 twice yearly, spring fall.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We never did go heavily to mail order houses except for stuff not carried in the local stores or where there was too much spread between local prices / Winnipeg or Regina prices. I couldn't guess what percentage went to outside points — guess maybe 10%.

Most purchases were for heavy winter clothing, curtains, linoleum & some classes of hardware.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some homesteaders moved up immediately sold out, disappeared from our Ken, but none of the original homesteaders or their families are still resident here.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father John Loring was appointed Post Master in 1908 in the Rural Office of Netherhill under the C.N.R. Service. In 1909 he moved to the Village continued as Post until his death in 1936. I was P.M. there until I resigned in 1946. John Loring was appointed J.P. in 1907, First Reeve of Netherhill Municipality 289 from its inception until about 1930 (approximate).

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

First comment on this: We had our first horses next, new tractors. We bought our first tractor in 1927. The first combine 1928, but there were tractors before this; maybe the only "first" was Robert Smith. The Loring's were the first settlers here; no one nearer than 20 miles to the east.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The School district Eagle Lake took its name from Eagle Lake 3 miles to the north. Afterward the school was moved to town changed to Netherhill S.D. NETHERHILL itself was named after an old home at Bechtel's in Scotland. The C.N.R. approved of Netherhill as the name of the Village situated on M-29. 21 W. 2.

In the maps Eagle Lake is called "Ki-yi" lake which we understand is either Cree or Blackfoot for "Eagle." The English version is the one used today.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

My family has been active in politics. My father was elected to the Board of Education in 1908. He served until 1912 when he moved to another town. In 1927, my brother was elected to the Board of Education. He served until 1930 when he moved to another town.

37. Is there anything else you would like to add?

Comment on this: We had our first horse in 1927. We purchased it from Mr. Smith. It was a beautiful animal. We used it for plowing and other farm work. We sold it in 1930 because we needed more money for farming.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School, district, etc.)

The school was named after the first teacher who taught there. The district was named after the first settler who lived there.

39. Tell me about the history of your town. When was it founded? Who were the founders?

Our town was founded in 1880 by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith. They came from England and brought their families with them. They built houses and started a school. The town grew quickly and became an important center for farming and trade.

40. Tell me about the local industries. Were they successful?

Our town had several industries. The most successful was the flour mill. It was owned by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith. They employed many people and produced high-quality flour. However, during the Great Depression, the mill closed down due to lack of demand.

41. Tell me about the local economy. Was it based on agriculture, industry, or services?

Our town's economy was based on agriculture. Many people farmed the land and sold their crops at the local market. However, during the Great Depression, many farms failed and the economy declined.

42. Tell me about the local government. Who were the leaders? What were their policies?

Our town had a mayor and a council. The mayor was elected every two years and the council members were appointed by the mayor. The policies included improving roads, building schools, and providing social services.

43. Tell me about the local culture. What were the main activities?

Our town had many cultural activities. The most popular was the annual fair. It attracted people from all over the county and featured music, games, and food. Other activities included the annual parade, the Christmas tree lighting ceremony, and the Fourth of July celebration.

44. Tell me about the local sports teams. Were they successful?

Our town had several sports teams. The most successful was the football team. They won many championships and were known for their strong defense. However, during the Great Depression, many teams disbanded due to lack of funding.

45. Tell me about the local parks and recreation areas. Were they popular?

Our town had several parks and recreation areas. The most popular was the community park. It had a playground, a basketball court, and a picnic area. People enjoyed playing sports and having picnics there.

46. Tell me about the local schools. What were the main subjects taught?

Our town had a single school building. It had classes for kindergarten through eighth grade. The main subjects taught were reading, writing, arithmetic, science, and social studies.

47. Tell me about the local libraries. Were they popular?

Our town had a small library. It was located in the town hall and had a collection of books for adults and children. People enjoyed borrowing books and attending book clubs.

48. Tell me about the local newspapers. Were they popular?

Our town had a weekly newspaper. It was called "The Local News" and was published by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith. It had news stories, advertisements, and opinion pieces. People enjoyed reading it and sharing their opinions.

49. Tell me about the local churches. What were the main denominations?

Our town had several churches. The most prominent was the Methodist Church. It had a large congregation and offered services in English and Spanish. Other churches included the Baptist Church and the Catholic Church.

50. Tell me about the local festivals. Were they popular?

Our town had several festivals throughout the year. The most popular was the annual festival in August. It featured music, food, and games. People enjoyed celebrating and enjoying each other's company.

51. Tell me about the local businesses. Were they successful?

Our town had several businesses. The most successful was the general store. It was owned by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith and sold a variety of goods. However, during the Great Depression, many businesses closed down due to lack of demand.

52. Tell me about the local transportation. Were they successful?

Our town had several modes of transportation. The most common was the horse-drawn carriage. However, during the Great Depression, many people could not afford horses and transportation declined.

53. Tell me about the local healthcare. Were they successful?

Our town had a small hospital. It was located in the town hall and had a few doctors and nurses. People enjoyed receiving care there and felt safe and secure.

54. Tell me about the local police force. Were they successful?

Our town had a small police force. It was led by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith. They patrolled the town and ensured safety and security. However, during the Great Depression, many people could not afford to pay fines and the police force declined.

Our town had a small fire department. It was led by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith. They responded to fires and emergencies and saved many lives. However, during the Great Depression, many people could not afford to pay fines and the fire department declined.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

As the only surviving son of John Craig, my family consists of John A. Craig, Imperial Oil Co., B.C.; Evelyn T. Craig, 19 years old, Royal Columbian Hosp., New Westminster; Elizabeth R. Craig, 18 years old, accepted as nurse in Vancouver, B.C.; Donald T. Craig, 12, student, "Neitherill School."

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Too big a question for me to answer properly. The country has changed, the outlook, living habits of the people have changed, education in the schools different, the old neighborhood has become a thing of the past. I believe that the custom of visiting on Sunday has vanished. If you do visit now, all you do is sit down, listen to the radio or play a rubber of bridge. Too bad but such is so-called progress.

When the Railroad Comes

There was at least one homesteader in the early years of this century who found time after his breaking and other pioneer chores to write poetry. He was W. A. McLeod, of Eagle Lake, whose 15-verse poem, "When the Railroad Comes," was published in The Daily Phoenix on August 25, 1908.

Names familiar to the hardy settlers who travelled the Bone Trail—the Bad Hills, Eagle Lake, Lake Opuntia and Netherhill—abound in the lively philosophical memories for oldtimers still living in west-central Saskatchewan.

When the railroad comes! Our trials will be over then;
We'll fret no more for fuel or a market for our grain;
We will work our farms to profit, we'll refill our empty pockets,
And our troubles will go from us with the coming of the train.

When the railroad comes you can buy your girl an auto
With the profit of your wheat fields, and have something besides;
You can live the way you ought to, you may work but haven't got to,
Your luck will turn a somersault and show its brightest side.

My friends, these dreams are foolish ones; since Eve first climbed
the apple tree
And Adam ate the core which Eve so kindly saved for him,
Poor man has had to till the soil with sweaty brow and anxious toil.

He need never hunt for trouble—trouble's busy hunting him.
When the railroad does come, we will notice the difference
Between the things we hope for and things as they really are;
We wonder how many cars we'll need to haul our wheat away.
We'll worry then for fear we won't have wheat to fill the car.

When the railroad comes—it cannot come to all of us;
Some will mourn in far-off valleys, some will curse on distant shores,
For the tinkling of the hammers filling many hearts with rapture
May be spiking fast the coffin lid on other people's hopes.

When the railroad comes, it will shock us most unpleasantly
To find we still must pay with cash for tools and clothes and board;
The greedy grocer man will still want money for his groceries,
The implement or lumber shark keeps adding to his hoard.

When the railroad comes, some will find to their astonishment
That trains may come and trains may go yet pocketbooks be slim
For eastbound freights will never wait on the man who has no wheel to sell,
And the fastest western-bound express will bring no wealth for him.

When the railroad comes, it will put an end to homesteading,
We cannot look a measly fifteen acres in the eye:
Our quarter section will shrink up—at first it looked immense to us,
And we'll plan to have a thousand-acre crop before we die.

When the railroad comes, we have no more of batching it,
We know by sad experience the woes of single life,
Clad in our sheepskin jackets we'll go home and pick the best of them,
For the girl who'll brave the West with us will make the finest wife.

When the railroad comes, we will see a gladsome exodus,
When men of the country does not need will want their land no more,
Then the grumbler and the doubter, the discouraged, and the lazy ones
Will pack their trunks and sell their bulls, and seek an easier shore.

When the railroad comes, we will boil with care our blankets,
We will bid farewell forever to the rotments of the trail,
We will pare our nails and cut our hair and no more say "Naughty blank its."
And each evening after supper we will read our daily mail.

But we'll miss the pleasant chat and hearty meals at stopping places,
At Layton's, Trail's and Hamilton's, Speers', Wilson's, Harris',
Bell's.

At Maurice's, Stafford's, Wylie Boys we often stopped for rations,
And however great our hurry, we would wait a meal at Scaells.
There's Bayley on the Town Line trail, and Bailey's "way out yonder,"
There's Craig still further "out beyond"—the squire of Netherhill,
There's Beaucier's and Pettigrew, Lelair and Carl and Carlson,
And Sutton and Van Eaton where we ate and drank our fill.

When the railroad comes, the city sports will visit us,
To the Bad Hills bush with rod and gun their merry way
They'll catch the speckled trout that swim in limpid Lake Opuntia,
And fish for land-locked salmon on the shores of Eagle Lake.

When the railroad comes; How this refrain wearies us
Which each newcomer with a fond anticipation hums:
We will work a blame sight harder, but we'll have a fatter larder,
And our hearts will all be glad—when the railroad comes.

W. A. McLEOD,
Eagle Creek, Sask.
July 30, 1908.
